text: P. c-album showing angular wings and typical comma marking Polygonia (from Greek πολύς - polys, "many"πολύς, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, A Greek- English Lexicon, on Perseus and γωνία - gōnia, "angle"γωνία, Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, A Greek-English Lexicon, on Perseus) is a genus of butterflies with a conspicuous white mark on the underside of each hindwing, hence the common name comma. They also have conspicuous angular notches on the outer edges of their forewings, hence the other common name anglewing butterflies. The related genus Nymphalis also includes some anglewing species; Polygonia is sometimes classified as a subgenus of Nymphalis."Nymphalis Kluk, 1780" at Markku Savela's Lepidoptera and Some Other Life Forms Many members of Polygonia hibernate as adults.Scott, J.
